title: Fibrosis of two: Epithelial cell-fibroblast interactions in pulmonary fibrosis
abstract: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is characterized by the progressive and ultimately fatal accumulation of fibroblasts and extracellular matrix in the lung that distorts its architecture and compromises its function. IPF is now thought to result from wound-healing processes that, although initiated to protect the host from injurious environmental stimuli, lead to pathological fibrosis due to these processes becoming aberrant or over-exuberant. Although the environmental stimuli that trigger IPF remain to be identified, recent evidence suggests that they initially injure the alveolar epithelium. Repetitive cycles of epithelial injury and resultant alveolar epithelial cell death provoke the migration, proliferation, activation and myofibroblast differentiation of fibroblasts, causing the accumulation of these cells and the extracellular matrix that they synthesize. In turn, these activated fibroblasts induce further alveolar epithelial cell injury and death, thereby creating a vicious cycle of pro-fibrotic epithelial cell-fibroblast interactions. Though other cell types certainly make important contributions, we focus here on the “ pas de deux ” (steps of two), or perhaps more appropriate to IPF pathogenesis, the “ folie à deux ” (madness of two) of epithelial cells and fibroblasts that drives the progression of pulmonary fibrosis. We describe the signaling molecules that mediate the interactions of these cell types in their “fibrosis of two”, including transforming growth factor-β, connective tissue growth factor, sonic hedgehog, prostaglandin E 2 , angiotensin II and reactive oxygen species. This article is part of a Special Issue entitled: Fibrosis: Translation of basic research to human disease. • Interactions between alveolar epithelial cells and fibroblasts are central to IPF. • Injured epithelial cells regulate fibroblasts through TGF-β, CTGF, Shh and PGE 2 . • Activated fibroblasts injure epithelial cells by producing angiotensin II and ROS. • Epithelial cell-fibroblast interaction may be a common theme in organ fibrosis.

motivations: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF) is a fatal disease characterized by the accumulation of fibroblasts and extracellular matrix in the lung, distorting its architecture and compromising its function.
The environmental stimuli that trigger IPF remain unknown, and the disease's pathogenesis is not fully understood.
objectives: Investigate the interactions between alveolar epithelial cells and fibroblasts in the progression of pulmonary fibrosis.

Identify the signaling molecules that mediate these cell-type interactions, including transforming growth factor-β, connective tissue growth factor, sonic hedgehog, prostaglandin E2, angiotensin II, and reactive oxygen species.
methods: Analyze the role of injured epithelial cells in regulating fibroblasts through various signaling molecules.
Examine the impact of activated fibroblasts on epithelial cells, including the production of angiotensin II and reactive oxygen species.
results: Elucidate the mechanisms underlying the vicious cycle of pro-fibrotic epithelial cell-fibroblast interactions in IPF.
Provide insights into the potential common theme of epithelial cell-fibroblast interaction in organ fibrosis.

motivations: Idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis is a fatal disease characterized by progressive accumulation of fibroblasts and extracellular matrix that destroys lung architecture and function.
The mechanisms driving the pathological interactions between epithelial cells and fibroblasts in pulmonary fibrosis remain incompletely understood.
objectives: Elucidate the bidirectional signaling mechanisms between alveolar epithelial cells and fibroblasts that drive pulmonary fibrosis progression.
Identify key molecular mediators of epithelial cell-fibroblast interactions in the context of IPF pathogenesis.
methods: Review and analyze the signaling pathways and molecules mediating epithelial cell-fibroblast interactions in pulmonary fibrosis.
Examine the role of specific mediators including TGF-β, CTGF, sonic hedgehog, PGE2, angiotensin II, and reactive oxygen species.
results: Identified a vicious cycle where injured epithelial cells activate fibroblasts, which in turn induce further epithelial injury through specific signaling molecules.
Established that epithelial cell-fibroblast interactions are central to IPF pathogenesis and may represent a common mechanism in organ fibrosis.
